title: Understanding Ovarian Cancer
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value:
Ovarian cancer begins in the ovaries — the organs that produce eggs and hormones such as oestrogen and progesterone.

Symptoms can be non-specific and may be mistaken for digestive or menstrual problems. Earlier diagnosis is associated with better treatment outcomes.

items.text: More common in women over 50
Often diagnosed at a later stage because symptoms can be non-specific
Epithelial ovarian cancer accounts for most cases
Symptoms can resemble digestive issues such as bloating

content.title: Remember
content.description: Ovarian cancer symptoms can be subtle. Persistent bloating, pelvic pain, and feeling full quickly should be checked. Awareness supports earlier detection.

content.value: Ovarian cancer can develop from different types of cells in the ovary or nearby fallopian tubes. Knowing where it starts helps guide diagnosis and treatment.

items.title: Epithelial Ovarian Cancer
items.description: The most common type (about 90% of cases). Many of these cancers are now thought to begin in the lining of the fallopian tubes before involving the ovary.

items.title: Germ Cell Tumours
items.description: Start in the cells that produce eggs. These are less common and often affect younger women.

items.title: Stromal Tumours
items.description: Begin in the hormone-producing cells of the ovary. They are rare and may cause hormone-related symptoms.

content.title: Did You Know?
content.description: Some cancers classified as ovarian cancer begin in the fallopian tubes but are grouped together because they behave in a similar way.

content.value: These factors can increase risk but do not mean you will develop ovarian cancer:

steps: Family history of ovarian, breast, or colorectal cancer
Inherited gene mutations such as BRCA1, BRCA2, or Lynch syndrome
Long-term hormone replacement therapy (risk varies depending on type and duration)

content.title: Good to Know
content.description: Having risk factors does not mean you will develop ovarian cancer. Awareness of risk factors and symptoms supports earlier medical assessment.

content.value: Ovarian cancer symptoms are often non-specific and may be mistaken for other conditions. Key symptoms to watch for include:

items.text: Persistent bloating or swollen abdomen
Pelvic or abdominal pain
Feeling full quickly or loss of appetite
Needing to urinate more often or urgently
changes in bowel habits
Indigestion
Back pain
Pain during sex
Extreme tiredness
Unexplained weight loss

content.title: Important
content.description: If these symptoms are new, persistent, and occur frequently (especially more than 12 times in a month), see your GP.

content.title: Diagnosis of Ovarian Cancer
content.description: If ovarian cancer is suspected, your doctor may arrange several tests to investigate further.

items.title: CA125 blood test
items.description: Measures a protein that can be raised in ovarian cancer

items.title: Pelvic ultrasound scan
items.description: Looks at the ovaries and surrounding organs

items.title: CT scan
items.description: used to see if cancer has spread and to plan treatment

items.title: Surgery or biopsy
items.description: Tissue may be examined to confirm the diagnosis

items.title: Laparoscopy
items.description: Occasionally used to look inside the abdomen

content.title: Note
content.description: These tests help confirm the diagnosis and determine how far the cancer has spread.

content.value: Treatment depends on the cancer type, stage, and your overall health.

content.title: Treatment Goal
content.description: The aim is to remove as much cancer as possible and treat any remaining disease

items.title: Surgery and chemotherapy
items.content: Often used together as first-line treatment

items.title: Targeted therapies
items.content: Such as PARP inhibitors or drugs that affect tumour blood supply, used in some cases

items.title: Radiotherapy
items.content: occasionally used for symptom control or selected recurrences.

items.title: Clinical trials
items.content: May offer access to new treatments

items.title: Supportive care
items.content: Therapies to improve comfort and wellbeing alongside medical treatment

content.value: While there is no routine screening test for ovarian cancer, understanding risk factors and symptoms is important.

content.title: Why Prevention Matters
content.description: Ovarian cancer symptoms can be non-specific. Knowing your risk factors and seeking medical advice for persistent symptoms can support earlier diagnosis.

content.value: Ways to help reduce your risk include:

items.text: Genetic testing if you have a strong family history
Long-term use of oral contraceptives (which is associated with reduced risk)
Maintaining a healthy body weight
Managing endometriosis with medical advice
Considering risk-reducing surgery if you carry BRCA1/BRCA2 mutations
Being aware of symptoms and seeking prompt medical evaluation
There is no routine screening test for ovarian cancer
Genetic testing can guide personalised prevention
Persistent bloating or pelvic pain should be checked
Earlier diagnosis is linked with better treatment outcomes

content.title: Key Takeaway
content.description: Although ovarian cancer cannot always be prevented, understanding your risk and responding to symptoms early can make an important difference.

content.value: Ovarian cancer symptoms can be non-specific and may be mistaken for common digestive problems. Awareness of symptoms is important, as earlier diagnosis is linked with better treatment outcomes.

items.text: Persistent bloating, pelvic pain, or feeling full quickly should be checked
Symptoms may be non-specific — noticing changes over time is important
Family history and inherited gene changes such as BRCA1/BRCA2 increase risk
There is no reliable screening test, so symptom awareness matters
Seeking medical advice early if symptoms persist is important

content.title: Final Message
content.description: Although ovarian cancer can be hard to detect early, recognising symptoms and understanding your risk can help you seek care promptly.
